o	As part of the external events analysis, items 2-6 were addressed. The expected completion date for recommendations from the last Process Hazard Analysis is September 2023.

4.9	Planned Changes To Improve Safety
The Process Hazard Analysis has been conducted to examine mitigation measures to improve safety at the facility. Planned changes to improve safety are listed as recommendations in the March 2021 Process Hazard Analysis Report. Any outstanding recommendations are planned to be addressed by September 2023. 

4.10	Toxics: Worst Case 
The use of toxic materials at Newport Butane - Irwindale Facility. is not encompassed by either the federal or state RMP requirements.  Therefore, this section is not applicable. 

4.11	Toxics: Alternative Release 
The use of toxic materials at Newport Butane - Irwindale Facility. is not encompassed by either the federal or state RMP requirements.  Therefore, this section is not applicable.

e part of the Newport Butane - Irwindale Facility CalARP Program Level 3 Compliance Workbook.  Please refer to each section of the CalARP Program for specific information.

4.6	Five-Year Accident History 
For any accidental release meeting the five-year accident history reporting criteria of 19 CCR §2750.9, the owner or operator shall submit the data required under 19 CCR §2745.5, §2745.6, and §2745.7 with respect to that accident within six months of the release or by the time the RMP is updated under 19 CCR §2745.10, whichever is earlier.  From 19 CCR §2750.9:
The owner or operator shall include in the five-year accident history all accidental releases from covered processes that resulted in deaths, injuries, or significant property damage on site, or known offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage.
Newport Butane - Irwindale Facility has had no releases in the last five years that meet the five-year accident history reporting criteria of 19 CCR §2750.9. 
Any incident or near miss that occurs at the Newport Butane - Irwindale Facility is investigated.  Please refer to the Incident Investigation Section of the CalARP Program Level 3 Compliance Workbook for specific information. 

4.7	Emergency Response Program
Newport Butane - Irwindale Facility is a non-responding facility and does not train employees for active responses to butane releases.  This facility will rely upon the local emergency hazardous materials response team and the local Fire Department for responses to uncontrolled releases of butane.  
In accordance with 19 CCR §2765.1, the facility is not required to have an Emergency Response Program in place.  They, however, are required to have appropriate mechanisms in place for notifying emergency responders when there is a need for response.  
The facility has submitted a Hazardous Material Inventory (HMI) via California Environmental Reporting System (CERS), and the Business Emergency

4.0	EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

4.1	Accidental Release Prevention
Newport Butane - Irwindale Facility has developed a risk management program and an emergency response plan to address CalARP Program requirements.  Newport Butane - Irwindale Facility has a long standing commitment to worker and public safety.  This commitment is demonstrated by the resources invested in accident prevention, such as personnel training and consideration of safety in the design, operation, and maintenance of the Butane Storage System.  Newport Butane - Irwindale Facility policy is to implement reasonable controls to prevent foreseeable releases of regulated substances. 

4.2	Stationary Source and Regulated Substance 
Newport Butane - Irwindale Facility is located at 15763 Ornelas Street Irwindale, CA 91706.  The regulated substance managed at the facility is butane. The maximum intended inventory is 84,000 pounds (lbs.) of butane.  The butane is stored in the regulated process but is processed and packaged elsewhere that is not covered in this process. 

4.3	Hazard Assessment Summary/Offsite Consequence Analysis 
Worst-Case Release Scenario Results Summary:
As per CalARP Regulations, one worst-case analysis has been defined and modeled for the butane storage system.  The results can be found in the Hazard Assessment documentation located behind the HAZARD ASSESSMENT Tab of the CalARP/RMP/PSM Program Level 3 Compliance Workbook.
Alternative Release Scenario Results Summary:
An alternative release scenario was modeled.  The results can be found in the Hazard Assessment documentation located behind the HAZARD ASSESSMENT Tab of the CalARP/RMP/PSM Program Level 3 Compliance Workbook.

4.4	Risk Considerations
Although the storage and use of butane has inherent potential risks, and worst-case release scenarios can potentially reach the community; Newport Butane - Irwindale Facility has recognized these potential risks and structured its safety programs to make the worst case type of even

t non-credible.  In addition to the safety practices of the company and plant personnel to make this worst-case event non-credible, it should also be recognized that there are inherent analysis assumptions that make the results of the atmospheric dispersion analysis appear worse than what would actually be expected during such event.
In addition to the use of conservative analysis assumptions that over-predict the effects of a potential release, other characteristics of the facility and site serve to minimize the potential risks associated with a butane release:
¿	Fire extinguishers
¿	Automatic sprinkler system

4.5	Accidental Release Prevention Program 
As part of the implementation of this CalARP Program, key Prevention Program elements were documented and implemented by Newport Butane - Irwindale Facility to manage process safety issues associated with the use of butane.  Furthermore, common industry standards, policies, and procedures are currently utilized to ensure safe practices are being performed.
The facility maximum intended inventory of butane is 84,000 lbs. Therefore, the regulated substance is under the 10,000-lbs. threshold for US EPA RMP, CalARP Program, and state threshold Cal/OSHA PSM. As a result, the butane covered process is subject to CalARP Program Level 3.
The Butane Prevention Program Level 3 elements include:
¿	Process Safety Information
¿	Process Hazard Analysis
¿	Operating Procedures
¿	Training
¿	Mechanical Integrity
¿	Compliance Audits
¿	Incident Investigation
¿	Management of Change
¿	Pre-Startup Safety Review
¿	Compliance Audits
¿	Incident Investigation
¿	Employee Participation
¿	Hot Work Permit
¿	Contractors
¿	Trade Secrets
In addition, key emergency response elements were addressed in the Hazardous Materials Business Plan.  See Emergency Response Program located in section 4.7 of this document. 
All the Prevention Program Level 3 Elements listed above, including the Emergency Response Program applicability, ar

Plan (BEP) has been filed with the Local Fire Department (Los Angeles County Fire Department - Health Hazardous Materials Division).  The Facility has procedures in place to evacuate the facility and notify responders when there is a need for a response.  A current copy of the Emergency Action Plan (EAP) can be found with the CEO.  A copy of the EAP has been provided in attachment A of the Emergency Response Program section for reference purposes.  The EAP includes:
¿	Evacuation Procedures
¿	Safety and Health Considerations
¿	Notification Procedures

4.8	External Events Analysis Information
Pursuant to the requirements of California Health & Safety Code, Title 19, Division 2, Chapter 4.5, §2745.7(q); the following external events analysis information shall be submitted:  
¿	The types of natural and human caused external events considered in PHA Section 2760.2.  
o	During the March 2021 Process Hazard Analysis, a broad list of external events was considered by the Team.  General events external to the plant that could conceivably cause a release of butane were addressed.  The External Events that were considered credible include, but are not limited to, earthquake, vandalism, sabotage, external fire, human error/misoperation, and vehicle impact.
¿	The estimated magnitude or scope of external events which were considered. If not known, the owner or operator of the stationary source shall work closely with the AA to determine what is required. If seismic events are applicable, the parameters used in the consideration of the seismic analysis and which edition of the Uniform Building Code was used when the process was designed.
o	The magnitudes of the external events considered are detailed within the PHA Worksheets and were qualitatively risk-ranked by the PHA Team. In addition, a Seismic Assessment was performed for the facility on April 12th, 2021 and a copy of the report can be located with the CalARP Coordinator.
